Description: Mould-made grey-ware pottery lamp with a double-convex body, a vertically pierced lug on the right side, a short tapering flat-topped nozzle with a rounded end, and a flat circular base. Worn particularly on base and top. Raised ridge around the oil pouring hole. Grey reduced Nile silt fabric. Black slip.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by McLean Museum and Art Gallery, Greenock. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

'Black ware' lamp with 2nd century BC parallels from Egypt (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q547, Q548, EA5220, EA5218) Marked in ink on underside: '190'? 'Black' or 'grey ware' pottery was produced at Memphis, and also at Naukratis. Parallels dated late 3rd to early 2nd century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, 20, Type A, Fig. 3, see also 5 and 6). Late 3rd to early 2nd century BC parallels from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.1). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.001) (Phase 1)
